title: Ohm’s Law Application
ques: A resistor of 10 ohms has a current of 2 A flowing through it. What is the voltage across the resistor?
explanation:
***Ohm's Law*** is given by the formula: ```V = IR```
Here, ***I*** is the current in amperes and ***R*** is the resistance in ohms.
Substituting the given values:
```V = 2 A * 10 ohms = 20 V```
So, ***the voltage across the resistor is 20 volts.***

title: Capacitor Charging
ques: What is the charge stored in a 5 μF capacitor connected to a 12 V battery?
explanation:
***Capacitance formula***: ```Q = CV```
Where ***Q*** is the charge, ***C*** is the capacitance, and ***V*** is the voltage.
Substitute: ```C = 5 μF = 5×10^-6 F```, ```V = 12 V```
```Q = 5×10^-6 F * 12 V = 60×10^-6 C = 60 μC```
***Thus, the capacitor stores 60 microcoulombs of charge.***

title: Magnetic Force on a Wire
ques: A wire of length 0.5 m carries a current of 4 A perpendicular to a magnetic field of 0.2 T. What is the magnetic force on the wire?
explanation:
***Magnetic force on a current-carrying wire***: ```F = ILB sin(θ)```
Here, the angle θ = 90°, so sin(θ) = 1.
Substitute: ```I = 4 A```, ```L = 0.5 m```, ```B = 0.2 T```
```F = 4 * 0.5 * 0.2 = 0.4 N```
***Hence, the force on the wire is 0.4 newtons.***

title: Faraday’s Law and Induced EMF
ques: A coil with 200 turns is placed in a magnetic field that changes from 0.3 T to 0 T in 0.1 s. The area of each loop is 0.01 m². What is the magnitude of the induced emf?
explanation:
***Faraday’s Law***: ```emf = -N * ΔΦ/Δt```, where Φ is the magnetic flux.
Flux change: ```ΔΦ = B_final * A - B_initial * A = 0 - 0.3 * 0.01 = -0.003 Wb```
Number of turns ***N = 200***, Time interval ***Δt = 0.1 s***
```emf = -200 * (-0.003)/0.1 = 0.6 V```
***The negative sign indicates direction, so magnitude is 0.6 V.***

title: AC Voltage Peak Value
ques: An alternating voltage has an RMS value of 100 V. What is its peak value?
explanation:
***RMS to Peak voltage conversion***: ```V_peak = √2 * V_rms```
Given: ```V_rms = 100 V```
```V_peak = 1.414 * 100 = 141.4 V```
***So, the peak voltage is approximately 141.4 volts.***

title: Power in a DC Circuit
ques: A 9 V battery is connected to a 3 ohm resistor. What is the power dissipated in the resistor?
explanation:
***Power in a resistor***: ```P = V^2 / R```
Substitute: ```V = 9 V```, ```R = 3 ohms```
```P = 81 / 3 = 27 W```
***The resistor dissipates 27 watts of power.***

title: Speed of Electromagnetic Waves
ques: What is the speed of electromagnetic waves in a vacuum?
explanation:
***Electromagnetic waves*** travel at a constant speed in vacuum:
```c = 3 × 10^8 m/s```
This is ***the speed of light in vacuum***, applicable to all electromagnetic waves like radio, light, X-rays, etc.

title: Resistors in Series
ques: Three resistors of 2 Ω, 4 Ω, and 6 Ω are connected in series. What is the total resistance?
explanation:
***Resistors in series*** simply add up:
```R_total = R1 + R2 + R3 = 2 + 4 + 6 = 12 Ω```
***So, the total resistance is 12 ohms.***

title: Voltage Divider Rule
ques: Two resistors of 3 Ω and 6 Ω are connected in series across a 9 V battery. What is the voltage across the 6 Ω resistor?
explanation:
To find voltage across a resistor in series, use the ***voltage divider rule***:
```V = (R / R_total) * V_total```
Total resistance: ```R_total = 3 + 6 = 9 Ω```
Voltage across 6 Ω: ```V = (6 / 9) * 9 = 6 V```
***So, the 6 Ω resistor has 6 V across it.***

title: Capacitor in a DC Circuit
ques: A capacitor is connected in series with a resistor and a DC battery. What is the final voltage across the capacitor after a long time?
explanation:
In a DC circuit, after a long time (steady state), ***the capacitor acts like an open circuit***.
No current flows, so ***voltage across the capacitor equals the battery voltage***.
Hence, ```V_capacitor = V_battery```.

title: Magnetic Field Around a Straight Wire
ques: What happens to the magnetic field around a straight current-carrying wire if the current is doubled?
explanation:
The magnetic field ***B*** around a straight wire is directly proportional to the current:
```B ∝ I```
So, if the current doubles, the magnetic field strength also doubles.
***This is a consequence of Ampère’s Law.***

title: Lenz’s Law Direction
ques: A magnet is moved toward a coil. What is the direction of the induced current in the coil?

answer.content: The induced current flows in a direction that opposes the motion of the magnet.

explanation:
***Lenz’s Law*** states that the induced current will oppose the change that caused it.
When a magnet is moved toward a coil, its magnetic flux increases.
To oppose this, the coil generates a magnetic field in the opposite direction.
***Thus, the induced current flows in a direction that creates a repelling magnetic field.***

title: Frequency in AC Circuit
ques: An AC source has a period of 0.02 seconds. What is its frequency?
explanation:
Frequency and period are inversely related:
```f = 1 / T```
Given: ```T = 0.02 s```
```f = 1 / 0.02 = 50 Hz```
***So, the AC supply has a frequency of 50 hertz.***

title: Current in a Parallel Circuit
ques: In a parallel circuit, one branch has a 4 Ω resistor with 2 A current. What is the voltage across that resistor?
explanation:
Each branch in a parallel circuit has the ***same voltage across it***.
Use ***Ohm’s Law***: ```V = IR```
```V = 2 A * 4 Ω = 8 V```
***The voltage across that branch is 8 volts.***

title: Electromagnetic Wave Components
ques: What are the two components of an electromagnetic wave and how are they oriented?

answer.content: Electric and magnetic fields, perpendicular to each other and to the direction of wave propagation.

explanation:
***Electromagnetic waves*** consist of:
1. An ***electric field***
2. A ***magnetic field***
These fields are ***perpendicular to each other*** and also ***perpendicular to the direction the wave travels***.
This is a defining characteristic of ***transverse waves***.

title: Power Factor in AC Circuits
ques: What is the power factor of a purely resistive AC circuit?
explanation:
In a purely resistive circuit, voltage and current are ***in phase***, so:
```θ = 0°```
Power factor: ```cos(0°) = 1```
***A power factor of 1 means all power is effectively used with no reactive losses.***

title: Electric Field Between Parallel Plates
ques: Two parallel plates are separated by 0.02 m and connected to a 100 V battery. What is the electric field between the plates?
explanation:
***Electric field between parallel plates*** is uniform and given by:
```E = V / d```
Where ***V = 100 V*** and ***d = 0.02 m***
```E = 100 / 0.02 = 5000 N/C```
***Thus, the electric field strength is 5000 newtons per coulomb.***

title: Energy Stored in a Capacitor
ques: Calculate the energy stored in a 10 μF capacitor charged to 15 V.
explanation:
***Energy in a capacitor*** is given by:
```E = 0.5 * C * V^2```
Where ***C = 10 μF = 10×10^-6 F*** and ***V = 15 V***
```E = 0.5 * 10×10^-6 * 225 = 1.125×10^-3 J```
***So, the capacitor stores 1.125 millijoules of energy.***

title: Induced Current in a Moving Loop
ques: A rectangular loop moves into a magnetic field of 0.4 T at a speed of 2 m/s. If the width of the loop is 0.1 m, what is the induced emf?
explanation:
When a conductor moves through a magnetic field, ***emf is induced***:
```emf = B * l * v```
Where ***B = 0.4 T***, ***l = 0.1 m***, ***v = 2 m/s***
```emf = 0.4 * 0.1 * 2 = 0.08 V```
***So, 0.08 volts is induced in the loop.***

title: Back EMF in a Motor
ques: A motor with a resistance of 5 Ω is connected to a 24 V battery and draws a current of 2 A. What is the back emf produced by the motor?
explanation:
***Back emf*** opposes the supply voltage in a motor:
```V_back = V_supply - IR```
Here, ***V_supply = 24 V***, ***I = 2 A***, ***R = 5 Ω***
```V_back = 24 - 10 = 14 V```
***So, the motor produces a back emf of 14 volts.***

title: Resonant Frequency in LC Circuit
ques: Find the resonant frequency of an LC circuit with L = 2 mH and C = 50 μF.
explanation:
***Resonant frequency*** of an LC circuit:
```f = 1 / (2π√(LC))```
Substitute: ```L = 2×10^-3 H```, ```C = 50×10^-6 F```
```f = 1 / (2π√(2×10^-3 * 50×10^-6)) ≈ 503.3 Hz```
***So, the circuit resonates at approximately 503.3 Hz.***

title: Transformer Voltage Change
ques: A step-down transformer has 500 turns on the primary and 100 turns on the secondary coil. If the input voltage is 220 V, what is the output voltage?
explanation:
Transformer voltage ratio:
```V_secondary / V_primary = N_secondary / N_primary```
Substitute: ```V_primary = 220 V```, ```N_p = 500```, ```N_s = 100```
```V_s = 220 * (100 / 500) = 44 V```
***So, the output voltage is 44 volts.***

title: Impedance of a Series RLC Circuit
ques: A 10 Ω resistor, 0.1 H inductor, and 100 μF capacitor are connected in series to a 50 Hz AC source. What is the total impedance?
explanation:
Impedance in RLC circuit:
```X_L = 2πfL = 2π * 50 * 0.1 ≈ 31.4 Ω```
```X_C = 1 / (2πfC) = 1 / (2π * 50 * 100×10^-6) ≈ 31.8 Ω```
```Z = √(R² + (X_L - X_C)²) = √(10² + (−0.4)²) ≈ √(100 + 0.16) ≈ 10.008 Ω```
***So, the total impedance is approximately 10.008 ohms.***

title: Polarization of EM Waves
ques: What happens during polarization of electromagnetic waves?

answer.content: The orientation of the electric field vector is restricted to one direction.

explanation:
***Polarization*** is a property of ***transverse waves*** like electromagnetic waves.
It restricts the oscillation of the ***electric field vector*** to a single plane.
***This helps reduce glare and is used in sunglasses, photography, and LCD screens.***

title: Ohm’s Law with Variable Resistance
ques: A wire has a resistance of 10 Ω at room temperature. If its resistance increases to 15 Ω due to heating and the voltage remains at 10 V, what happens to the current?

answer.content:
Initial current = 10 V / 10 Ω = 1 A
Final current = 10 V / 15 Ω ≈ 0.67 A

explanation:
***Ohm’s Law***: ```I = V / R```
Initial: ```I = 10 / 10 = 1 A```
Final (after resistance increases): ```I = 10 / 15 ≈ 0.67 A```
***As resistance increases, current decreases when voltage is constant.***

title: Charge Stored in a Capacitor
ques: A capacitor of 20 μF is charged to a potential difference of 12 V. What is the charge stored?
explanation:
***Capacitor charge formula***: ```Q = C × V```
Given: ```C = 20 μF = 20×10^-6 F```, ```V = 12 V```
```Q = 20×10^-6 × 12 = 2.4×10^-4 C```
***So, 0.24 millicoulombs of charge is stored.***

title: Current in a Magnetic Field
ques: A straight conductor 0.5 m long carries a current of 4 A and is placed perpendicular to a magnetic field of 0.2 T. What is the magnetic force on it?
explanation:
***Magnetic force on current-carrying wire***: ```F = BIL sin(θ)```
Since the wire is perpendicular: ```sin(90°) = 1```
```F = 0.2 × 4 × 0.5 = 0.4 N```
***So, the force on the wire is 0.4 newtons.***

title: Magnetic Flux Through a Loop
ques: A loop of area 0.01 m² is placed in a magnetic field of 0.5 T perpendicular to the plane. What is the magnetic flux through the loop?
explanation:
***Magnetic flux*** is given by: ```Φ = B × A × cos(θ)```
Here, field is perpendicular ⇒ ```θ = 0°``` ⇒ ```cos(0°) = 1```
```Φ = 0.5 × 0.01 = 0.005 Wb```
***So, the magnetic flux through the loop is 0.005 weber.***

title: Time Constant of an RC Circuit
ques: What is the time constant of an RC circuit with R = 1 kΩ and C = 100 μF?
explanation:
***Time constant (τ)*** in an RC circuit: ```τ = R × C```
Given: ```R = 1000 Ω```, ```C = 100 μF = 100×10^-6 F```
```τ = 1000 × 100×10^-6 = 0.1 s```
***So, the capacitor charges significantly over about 0.1 seconds.***

title: AC Voltage in RMS
ques: What is the RMS value of an AC voltage with a peak value of 170 V?
explanation:
***RMS value of AC voltage***: ```Vrms = Vpeak / √2```
```Vrms = 170 / 1.414 ≈ 120 V```
***This is why standard household AC in many countries is 120 V RMS.***

title: Direction of Induced EMF
ques: A loop rotates clockwise in a magnetic field. What rule determines the direction of the induced current?

answer.content: Lenz's Law and the Right-Hand Rule

explanation:
***Lenz’s Law*** tells us the direction of induced current opposes the change in magnetic flux.
The ***Right-Hand Rule*** helps visualize the magnetic field, motion, and current direction.
***Together, they determine how the current flows during rotation in a magnetic field.***

title: Speed of Electromagnetic Wave in Vacuum
ques: What is the speed of all electromagnetic waves in a vacuum?
explanation:
All electromagnetic waves — radio, light, X-rays — travel at the ***speed of light in vacuum***:
```c = 3 × 10^8 m/s```
***This value is constant and fundamental to all electromagnetic wave propagation in space.***

title: Series and Parallel Resistors
ques: Three resistors of 4 Ω, 6 Ω, and 12 Ω are connected in parallel. What is the equivalent resistance of the circuit?
explanation:
***Parallel resistance formula***: ```1/R_eq = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3```
```1/R_eq = 1/4 + 1/6 + 1/12 = (3 + 2 + 1)/12 = 6/12```
```R_eq = 2 Ω```
***So, the equivalent resistance is 2 ohms.***

title: Electric Field at a Point Charge
ques: Calculate the electric field 0.2 m away from a point charge of 5 μC in vacuum.
explanation:
***Electric field of a point charge***: ```E = k*q/r²```
Where ```k = 9×10^9 Nm²/C²```, ```q = 5×10^-6 C```, ```r = 0.2 m```
```E = 9×10^9 * 5×10^-6 / 0.04 = 1.125×10^6 N/C```
***So, the electric field strength is 1.125 million newtons per coulomb.***

title: Mutual Induction in Coils
ques: When the current in a coil is changed at a rate of 2 A/s and it induces 0.1 V in a nearby coil, what is the mutual inductance?
explanation:
***Mutual inductance*** is defined as:
```M = emf / (ΔI/Δt)```
Given: ```emf = 0.1 V```, ```ΔI/Δt = 2 A/s```
```M = 0.1 / 2 = 0.05 H```
***So, the mutual inductance between the coils is 0.05 henrys.***

title: Average Power in AC Circuit
ques: An AC circuit has Vrms = 100 V and Irms = 5 A with a phase angle of 60°. What is the average power consumed?

answer.content: P = Vrms * Irms * cos(ϕ) = 100 * 5 * cos(60°) = 250 W

explanation:
***Average power in AC***: ```P = Vrms * Irms * cos(ϕ)```
Given: ```Vrms = 100 V```, ```Irms = 5 A```, ```cos(60°) = 0.5```
```P = 100 * 5 * 0.5 = 250 W```
***So, the circuit consumes 250 watts of average power.***

title: Frequency of Electromagnetic Waves
ques: What is the frequency of an electromagnetic wave with a wavelength of 3 m in vacuum?
explanation:
***Wave speed relation***: ```f = c / λ```
Given: ```c = 3×10^8 m/s```, ```λ = 3 m```
```f = 3×10^8 / 3 = 1×10^8 Hz```
***So, the frequency of the wave is 100 MHz.***

title: Charging a Capacitor Over Time
ques: In an RC charging circuit with R = 2 kΩ and C = 50 μF, how long does it take to reach 63% of the final voltage?
explanation:
At time ```t = RC```, a capacitor charges to about ***63%*** of its final voltage.
Given: ```R = 2000 Ω```, ```C = 50×10^-6 F```
```t = RC = 2000 * 50×10^-6 = 0.1 s```
***So, it takes 0.1 seconds to charge to 63%.***

title: Self-Induced EMF in a Coil
ques: A coil with inductance 0.3 H experiences a decrease in current at 4 A/s. What is the induced emf?
explanation:
***Self-induced emf*** is given by:
```emf = -L * (ΔI/Δt)```
Where ```L = 0.3 H```, ```ΔI/Δt = 4 A/s```
```emf = -0.3 * 4 = -1.2 V```
***Negative sign shows the emf opposes the change (Lenz’s Law).***

title: Power Dissipation in a Resistor
ques: How much power is dissipated in a 20 Ω resistor carrying 3 A of current?
explanation:
***Power dissipation*** in resistors: ```P = I²R```
Given: ```I = 3 A```, ```R = 20 Ω```
```P = 9 * 20 = 180 W```
***So, 180 watts of power is dissipated as heat.***

title: Capacitor Energy Storage
ques: A 10 μF capacitor is charged to a potential difference of 30 V. How much energy is stored in the capacitor?
explanation:
***Energy stored in a capacitor***: ```U = 0.5 × C × V²```
```C = 10 μF = 10×10^-6 F```, ```V = 30 V```
```U = 0.5 × 10×10^-6 × 900 = 4.5×10^-3 J```
***So, 4.5 millijoules of energy is stored in the capacitor.***

title: Resistor Voltage Drop in Series
ques: In a series circuit with a 12 V battery and two resistors (3 Ω and 9 Ω), what is the voltage drop across the 9 Ω resistor?
explanation:
***Total resistance***: ```R_total = 3 + 9 = 12 Ω```
***Total current***: ```I = V / R_total = 12 / 12 = 1 A```
***Voltage drop across 9 Ω***: ```V = IR = 1 × 9 = 9 V```
***So, 9 volts drops across the 9 Ω resistor.***

title: Faraday's Law of Induction
ques: A coil of 50 turns experiences a magnetic flux change of 0.02 Wb in 0.1 s. What is the induced emf?
explanation:
***Faraday’s Law***: ```emf = -N × (ΔΦ / Δt)```
Given: ```N = 50```, ```ΔΦ = 0.02 Wb```, ```Δt = 0.1 s```
```emf = -50 × (0.02 / 0.1) = -10 V```
***So, the induced emf is -10 volts. The negative sign indicates opposition (Lenz’s Law).***

ques: An AC source of 100 V and 50 Hz is connected to a 100 μF capacitor. What is the current?

title: Induced Current Direction
ques: If a magnet is moved toward a loop of wire, in which direction is the induced current?

answer.content: Opposite to the magnetic field increase (Lenz’s Law)

explanation:
***Lenz’s Law***: The induced current opposes the change causing it.
As the magnet approaches, magnetic flux increases.
To oppose this, the loop induces current in a direction that creates an opposing magnetic field.
***So, the induced current flows opposite to the field’s increase.***

title: Root Mean Square Current
ques: If the peak current in an AC circuit is 7 A, what is the RMS current?
explanation:
***RMS current***: ```Irms = Ipeak / √2```
Given: ```Ipeak = 7 A```
```Irms = 7 / 1.414 ≈ 4.95 A```
***So, the RMS current is approximately 4.95 amperes.***

title: Polarization of EM Waves
ques: Which direction does the electric field oscillate in a vertically polarized electromagnetic wave?

answer.content: It oscillates vertically, perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation.

explanation:
In ***electromagnetic waves***, the electric and magnetic fields are perpendicular to each other and to the direction of wave propagation.
In a ***vertically polarized*** wave, the ***electric field oscillates vertically***.
***This means it's perpendicular to the wave’s travel direction and lies in a vertical plane.***

title: DC Motor Working Principle
ques: Which principle allows a DC motor to rotate when current flows through its coil?
explanation:
When current flows through a coil in a magnetic field, it experiences a ***Lorentz Force***.
This force acts differently on each side of the loop, creating a ***torque***.
The torque causes the motor coil to rotate — this is the basic principle behind ***DC motors***.
***So, Lorentz force and resulting torque drive the motor's rotation.***

title: Electric Field Between Parallel Plates
ques: Two parallel plates are 5 mm apart and have a potential difference of 500 V. What is the electric field between the plates?
explanation:
***Electric field between plates***: ```E = V / d```
Given: ```V = 500 V```, ```d = 5 mm = 0.005 m```
```E = 500 / 0.005 = 1×10^5 N/C```
***So, the electric field between the plates is 100,000 N/C.***

title: Resistor Power Rating
ques: A 10 Ω resistor is connected to a 12 V battery. What is the power dissipated by the resistor?
explanation:
***Power in resistor using voltage and resistance***: ```P = V² / R```
Given: ```V = 12 V```, ```R = 10 Ω```
```P = 144 / 10 = 14.4 W```
***So, 14.4 watts of power is dissipated by the resistor.***

title: Flux Through a Coil
ques: A 20-turn coil lies in a magnetic field of 0.3 T. The area of each loop is 0.01 m². What is the total magnetic flux through the coil?
explanation:
***Magnetic flux through a coil***: ```Φ = N × B × A```
Given: ```N = 20```, ```B = 0.3 T```, ```A = 0.01 m²```
```Φ = 20 × 0.3 × 0.01 = 0.06 Wb```
***So, total magnetic flux through the coil is 0.06 weber.***

title: Reactance of an Inductor
ques: What is the inductive reactance of a 0.1 H coil connected to a 60 Hz AC supply?
explanation:
***Inductive reactance***: ```X_L = 2πfL```
Given: ```f = 60 Hz```, ```L = 0.1 H```
```X_L = 2π × 60 × 0.1 = 37.7 Ω```
***So, the inductor presents about 37.7 ohms of reactance.***

title: AC Voltage Equation
ques: An AC source produces a peak voltage of 170 V. Write the expression for the instantaneous voltage if frequency is 50 Hz.
explanation:
***Instantaneous voltage for AC***: ```V(t) = V_peak × sin(2πft)```
Given: ```V_peak = 170 V```, ```f = 50 Hz```
```V(t) = 170 sin(2π × 50 × t)```
***This expression describes the voltage as a sine wave in time.***

title: Capacitor Discharge Time
ques: In an RC circuit with R = 5 kΩ and C = 200 μF, how long does it take for the capacitor to discharge to 37% of its initial voltage?
explanation:
***Discharge time constant***: ```τ = RC```
Given: ```R = 5000 Ω```, ```C = 200 μF = 200×10^-6 F```
```τ = 5000 × 200×10^-6 = 1 s```
***At t = RC, voltage drops to about 37% of its initial value.***

title: Direction of Magnetic Field
ques: A current flows upward through a vertical wire. What is the direction of the magnetic field around the wire?

answer.content: The field circles the wire in a counterclockwise direction when viewed from above.

explanation:
***Right-hand rule***: Point the thumb in the direction of current (upward).
Fingers curl in the direction of the magnetic field.
***So, the magnetic field is circular and counterclockwise when viewed from the top.***

title: Speed of EM Waves in Glass
ques: The refractive index of glass is 1.5. What is the speed of light through glass?
explanation:
***Speed of light in a medium***: ```v = c / n```
Given: ```c = 3×10^8 m/s```, ```n = 1.5```
```v = 3×10^8 / 1.5 = 2×10^8 m/s```
***So, light travels at 200 million meters per second in glass.***
